content: I know the concrete construction of coproducts of monoids in Set\mathbf{Set}Set but I am unaware of how to do it category-theoretically rather than syntactically even in the special case of Set\mathbf{Set}Set never mind anything that works in a more general context. Does anyone know or have a reference to such a construction?

(I guess I do know a way: I could use the general construction of coproducts for monad algebras from Adamek and Koubek together with the construction of coequalizers from Porst but I was hoping for something maybe a bit more direct.)
@William Troiani looked at this in his Masters thesis ; I'm tagging him since he's produced cleaner exposition of it since, I think.
Oh wait I apparently completely misread your question. William does coproducts of sets, syntactically. Almost entirely unrelated. Please disregard.
An article that might be related is A unified treatment of transfinite constructions for free algebras, free monoids, colimits, associated sheaves, and so on by Kelly

Let's see... To construct the coproduct of two monoids, you take the coproduct of their underlying sets, take the free structure on that (so we're at ∐n≥0(A+B)n\coprod_{n \geq 0} (A + B)^n∐n≥0​(A+B)n so far) and quotient by an equivalence relation generated by multiplication of adjacent terms when applicable, so (A+B)n∋uaa′v∼u(μA(a,a′))v∈(A+B)n−1(A+B)^n \ni uaa'v \sim u(\mu_A(a,a'))v \in (A+B)^{n-1}(A+B)n∋uaa′v∼u(μA​(a,a′))v∈(A+B)n−1, where u∈(A+B)ku \in (A+B)^ku∈(A+B)k and a,a′∈Aa,a' \in Aa,a′∈A and v∈(A+B)n−k−2v \in (A+B)^{n-k-2}v∈(A+B)n−k−2 (and similarly for elements of BBB), plus the relation ∗∼1A∼1B* \sim 1_A \sim 1_B∗∼1A​∼1B​, where ∗*∗ is the unique element of (A+B)0(A+B)^0(A+B)0. I can see why you would want to streamline that.

Oh right, expanding the syntactic construction, we can do the following:
Present a monoid MMM as an algebra TM→MTM \to MTM→M for the free monoid monad TTT (for TMTMTM the free monoid on the underlying set of MMM); taking the kernel pair of this map gives the congruence RM⇉TMR_M \rightrightarrows TMRM​⇉TM defining MMM. Doing this for monoids A,BA,BA,B, we have RA⇉TA→T(A+B)←TB⇇RBR_A \rightrightarrows TA \rightarrow T(A+B) \leftarrow TB \leftleftarrows R_BRA​⇉TA→T(A+B)←TB⇇RB​ defining two relations on T(A+B)T(A+B)T(A+B), of which we can take the union. Taking the standard transitive and reflexive closure of this relation, we obtain the congruence on T(A+B)T(A+B)T(A+B) that I described inefficiently above. It's still cumbersome, but at least it's clearly categorical.
(It feels like I'm missing part of the relation this way, so it needs checking, but that should be the flavour of the construction)
Seems like that gives the underlying set of the monoid but where does the algebra structure come from?
Hm, actually maybe it doesn't even give the underlying set, there's no quotienting done on strings that mix AAA s and BBB s when you implement this in Set.
Right, you need it to be a congruence, not just an equivalence relation. I suppose that's somehow the crux of the construction

(A+B)n≃∑0≤k≤nAkBn−k(A+B)^n \simeq \underset{0 \le k \le n}{\sum}A^kB^{n-k}(A+B)n≃0≤k≤n∑​AkBn−k
But in fact maybe you can work without distributivity if you directly use the right-hand side expression i.e. the
Mn=∑0≤k≤nAkBn−kM_n=\underset{0 \le k \le n}{\sum}A^kB^{n-k}Mn​=0≤k≤n∑​AkBn−k

After this, you could try defining a PnP_nPn​ as a coequalizer of a whole bunch of maps from MnM_nMn​ to MnM_nMn​ which do every possible combinations of multiplying and then inserting units both in the AkA^kAk and in the Bn−kB^{n-k}Bn−k and then take the colimit PPP of a diagram of the form
…Pn→Pn+1→…\dots P_n \rightarrow P_{n+1} \rightarrow \dots…Pn​→Pn+1​→…
where the arrow from PnP_nPn​ to Pn+1P_{n+1}Pn+1​ is an inclusion map inherited from the inclusion Mn→Mn+1M_n \rightarrow M_{n+1}Mn​→Mn+1​.

Of course making this precise and checking that everything works fine should be a bit of work.

Second of course: defining the multiplication and unit of PPP will be a bit of work also... and checking the associativity and unitality as well.

Also, sorry I supposed that you wanted to define the coproduct of monoids in an arbitrary category with products but I don't know if it is what you wanted to do.

I've just realized that what I've sketched must work in any monoidal category (no need for the monoidal product to be a cartesian product), producing also the coproduct of non-commutative rings (and non necessarily commutative kkk-algebras as well I guess).

But I get it that if AAA or BBB is free, then things will be easier. As it is easier if we're looking at commutative monoids.
